Award.AwardTitle: EARS: Collaborative Research: Intelligence Measure of Cognitive Radio Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research on spectrum sharing has generated a large amount of spectrum measurement data and many spectrum sharing techniques. Most of the techniques are based on cognitive radio networks (CRNs) because the cognition capability is necessary for optimizing spectrum efficiency and guaranteeing safe coexistence in the presence of the spectrum uncertainty. Such cognitive capabilities collectively defines the intelligence of CRNs. Although cognition and intelligence are vital for CRNs, their quantitative specification is largely open.

This project addresses this open question by developing a framework for investigating quantitatively the cognitive capabilities and the intelligence of CRNs. This project develops both a theoretical approach and an empirical approach to construct a CRN intelligence model. This model is inspired from the Cattell-Horn-Carroll human intelligence model. On the other hand, the pioneering theoretical approach is in sharp contrast to conventional human intelligence research that is mainly empirical. In addition, this project develops a CRN testing battery to measure the intelligence as CRN IQ (intelligence quotient) following psychometric practices. Finally, this project initiates innovative research in IQ-based multi-hop routing and IQ-based immunity to Denial-of-Service attacks, where innovative CRN techniques are developed with the aim of enhancing important cognitive capabilities. This project adopts a big data approach to exploit the vast amount of existing spectrum measurement data and CRN research results. Psychometric techniques are exploited to resolve challenges involved in this big data application.

This project impacts society by expediting the commercial success of spectrum sharing technology. It integrates three traditionally disparate areas: wireless communications, psychology, and big data. The framework for constructing intelligence measure is useful to many other systems such as cognitive computing, cognitive control and cognitive radar. This project enhances the value of the spectrum measurement data and leads to a new direction for big data utilization. This project impacts education in many aspects, such as stimulating student research via the human intelligence analogy, supporting hands-on curriculum with the CRN testing battery, setting up CRN IQ competition projects, and outreaching to under-represented students and high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cognitive capabilities of cognitive radio networks (CRNs), which collectively determine the intelligence of CRNs, are fundamental concepts for CRNs and are important for CRNs to conduct successful spectrum sharing in uncertain environment. Nevertheless, while CRNs have been investigated extensively, their cognitive capability or intelligence has never been defined or studied in a quantitative manner. To fill this gap, the overall objective of this project is to develop an intelligence measure to evaluate quantitatively the cognitive capability of cognitive radios and CRNs, and to use the intelligence measure to enhance the coexistence and spectrum efficiency of CRNs in uncertain environment.

One of the primary outcomes of this project is that a valid CRN intelligence model is developed based on a popular human intelligence model, i.e., the widely accepted Cattell-Horn-Carrol (CHC) intelligence model. The spectrum of human cognitive capabilities is adapted to define CRN cognitive capabilities. A data driven methodology is developed to quantitatively measure the intelligence factors or cognition capabilities of CRNs. The basic idea of this methodology is to run a large number of tests on the CRNs in different communication environments under various CRN parameter settings, which generates a large amount of performance data over various performance metrics. Then factor analysis is applied on the performance data to identify and quantize the intelligence factors. In a case study involving 144 different types of cognitive radios, five intelligence factors are identified through this approach. These factors comply well with the nature of the cognitive radio’s capabilities, and can be explained well under the CHC-inspired CRN intelligence model. 

The second primary outcome of this project is that a theoretical framework is developed to evaluate the general cognitive capability of CRNs. Under the CHC-inspired CRN intelligence model, this framework includes strategies for measuring quantitatively the intelligence level of CRNs as intelligence quotient (IQ). Specifically, this framework develops the optimal CRN testing questionnaires based on the item response theory as well as the CRN characteristics, and evaluate the testing results on a scale similar to the human intelligence quotient (IQ). Since human IQ test provides a straightforward quantitative description of a person’s capability in conducting certain types of tasks like logical thinking, the CRN’s IQ measure will lay down a useful strategy for the general cognition quantification of CRNs.

The third primary outcome of this project is the development of a set of innovative techniques for mitigating primary user emulation (PUE) attacks. Some novel algorithms have been developed for this purpose, including algorithms based on physically unclonable features of CRNs, algorithms based on singular spectrum analysis (SSA), and algorithms based on deep recurrent neural networks. To deal with the problem of limited data amount and noisy data, which is a special challenge to the application of big data analysis and deep learning to CRN research, robust deep learning techniques are developed, which can enhance the performance of deep learning algorithms for both PUE attack detection and conventional classification applications.

This project builds the underlying theoretical foundation to support the development of new CRN and spectrum sharing techniques that will enhance the spectrum efficiency of wireless communications in uncertain environment. Techniques developed in this project are important for the next generation wireless communication systems. The theoretical framework for the intelligence measure of CRNs is helpful for many other intelligent engineering systems in general. This project has promoted the integration of the traditionally disparate areas: wireless communications, human intelligence, cognitive science, as well as data science.
